newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech PM Klaus says sees Q1 GDP at about 0.0 pct.
newsitem.headline: Czech PM Klaus says sees Q1 GDP at about 0.0 pct.

text.p: Czech Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus on Tuesday said he expected real GDP growth for the first quarter to be "about zero percent", year-on-year, after growth of 4.6 percent in the first three months of 1996.

"I wouldn't be surprised if we will be somewhere around zero percent (GDP)," Klaus said at a lecture at the Prague School of Economics. "I suppose the acceleration of growth (GDP) in 1998 will be somewhere between 3-4 percent," he added.
Industrial output in the Czech Republic contracted in the first two months of 1997.
The trade deficit hit a record 160.3 billion crowns in 1996, and is expected to surge to some 200 billion this year.
The Czech economy recorded real growth of 4.4 percent in 1996, but a downturn in industry has sent economists scrambling to revise their forecasts downward.
On April 16, the government announced a series of economic measures aimed at reviving the economy while easing pressures from a burgeoning trade deficit and rising wages.
During the announcement, Klaus said he would consider it a success if Czech real GDP growth was 2.7 percent, one-half of the government's original estimate for 1997.
